Section 8002 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow local educational agencies formed by the consolidation of former school districts to elect for eligibility and funding to be determined based on designated former districts. The local educational agency must have applied for and been determined eligible under a specific Act for fiscal year 1994 or earlier to qualify for funding. The Secretary must pay at least 85% of the agency's previous year's funding for fiscal year 1995, with exceptions. If necessary, payments to local educational agencies may be reduced ratably under certain conditions. Additional funds may increase reduced payments under subsection (b) on the same basis. Payments to local educational agencies may be reduced if funds are insufficient, but will be increased if additional funds become available. SEC. 2. APPLICATIONS FOR INCREASED PAYMENTS. Payments for certain school districts in South Dakota for fiscal year 1994 under Public Law 874, 81st Congress, are eligible. The Secretary of Education will use a subgroup of comparable local educational agencies to calculate payments. School districts must apply within 30 days of the enactment of the Act to receive the payment. The subsection requires school districts in South Dakota to apply within 30 days of the Act's enactment to receive payments under Public Law 874. No local educational agency that received a payment for fiscal year 1994 is required to return any portion of the payment to the Federal Government. SEC. 3. Payments for eligible federally connected children residing on military installation housing undergoing renovation. Payments for eligible federally connected children residing on military installation housing undergoing renovation. Amendment to Section 8003(a) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 allows the Secretary to consider children affected by housing renovation as if they resided in Federal property for payment calculations. Effective Date for the amendment to Section 8003(a) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is applicable for fiscal years after 1995. SEC. 4. COMPUTATION OF PAYMENTS FOR ELIGIBLE FEDERALLY CONNECTED CHILDREN IN STATES WITH ONLY ONE LOCAL EDUCATIONAL AGENCY. The amendment to Section 8003(b) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 states that in states with only one local educational agency, each administrative school district will be considered a separate local educational agency for funding purposes. This includes computing the maximum payment amount and learning opportunity threshold payment for these districts. The Secretary determines the maximum payment amount and total current expenditures for the state before calculating funding for each administrative school district. The Secretary determines the maximum payment amount and total current expenditures for the state before allocating funds to administrative school districts based on student units and attendance. This provision applies to fiscal years after 1994. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to require local educational agencies to use data from the second fiscal year prior to applying for assistance. Amendments regarding the allocation of funds exceeding 30 percent of the agency's operating costs will apply to fiscal years after 1996. SEC. 6. PAYMENTS RELATING TO FEDERAL PROPERTY. Section 8002 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize payments to local educational agencies serving school districts with United States military academies, using excess funds to increase payments up to 50 percent of the maximum amount determined under subsection (b). The amendment to Section 8002 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 prioritizes payments to local educational agencies serving school districts with United States military academies. The amendment requires that the school district has at least 60 percent federally owned real property and maintains per-pupil revenue from local sources for current expenditures equal to or greater than the previous fiscal year. SEC. 7. TREATMENT OF IMPACT AID PAYMENTS. The Secretary of Education will consider a State as meeting certain requirements for fiscal year 1991 but not for the following years if specific conditions are met regarding the State's program of State aid certification. The State must meet specific requirements for fiscal year 1991 to make payments to local educational agencies, ensuring they receive the correct amount of funding under the Act of September 30, 1950. Repayment is not required for agencies meeting these conditions. The State is not required to repay funds to the Secretary of Education for fiscal year 1991 under Public Law 874, 81st Congress, if specific requirements are met by local educational agencies. The Secretary of Education will not count funds designated for future liabilities under an early retirement program for the North Hanover Township Public Schools in New Jersey when determining eligibility for payments in fiscal year 1994 under Public Law 874. Additionally, there is a provision for a corrected local contribution rate. The Secretary of Education will compute payments for local educational agencies for fiscal years 1991 through 1994 using a corrected local contribution rate if an incorrect rate was submitted and verified as correct. Payments will be made using funds appropriated under Public Law 874 for those years. For fiscal years 1991 through 1994, the Secretary of Education will make payments to local educational agencies based on correct contribution rates. SEC. 10. STATE EQUALIZATION PLANS. Amends section 8009(b)(2) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to specify that more than 25 percent is the threshold for certain payments to local educational agencies.
